dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Because they think I have writer's block. Penny looks for a way to change the subject.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: (sees pages on floor) Are those pages?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: They're letters. To me.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Are you writing back? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Penny looks at her with a looming eye.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: No. Penny comes over to pick up the letters. She notices the cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: . PENNY
dialogues.text: Ah. And I imagine you smoked all these. cigarettes?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: No. They came pre-smoked.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: (without even a smile) Right. They mentioned you were funny. Well... please... don't let me distract you. Kay steps to the other edge of the table, finds a cigaret in a tissue and lights it.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: What do you think about leaping off a building?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I don't think about leaping off a building.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Yes you do.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: No. I try to think of nice things.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Everyone thinks about leaping off a building. Everyone.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Well, I certainly don't think about thinking about leaping off a building.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: They say-- I read this in this fantastically depressing book-- that when you jump from a building, it's rarely the impact that actually kills you.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sure it doesn't help.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: There's a... There's a photograph in it, a photograph, from the L.A. Times around forty years ago. Called "The Leaper".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's old but... it's beautiful. From above the corpse of a woman who had just leapt to her death. There's, there's blood around her head..- like a halo. And her leg is... buckled underneath her. And her arm has snapped like a twig. (pause) But her face is so serene. So at peace. (pause) And I think it's because when she died... she could feel the wind against her face. Kay puts out her cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (with vulnerability) I don't know how to kill Harold Crick.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: (reassuringly) I know. I've heard.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I can't just... It has to be perfect: exact, specific, poetic but not...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I... I just... (sighs) As much as I'd like to, I can't just throw Harold off a building.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Ms. Eiffel. Kay. I have been an assistant for 18 years. I have helped more than 20 authors complete more than 35 books. I have never missed a deadline. I have never lost a writer to a block for longer than three weeks. I will be available to you every minute of every day of every week until the final punctuation is embedded on the final page. I do not like loud music. I do not abide narcotics. I prefer to be called Penny, not Ms. Escher. And I will gladly and quietly help you kiil Harold Crick so we may both go on with our respective lives. (pause} And if you'll allow me, I think it would benefit you greatly if you'd cut back on the smoking.  20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later that afternoon, Harold arrives at his desk at the e of a long row of cubicles to find a note taped to his com monitor. © He peels the note off and reads it: "Let's chat! —Dr. Cayly" Harold just sighs-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The open layout allows for noise and activity spillage fr the day care center into the common area right outside th door of Dr. Cayly's office. Currently, three four-year-ol are building a tower out of Lego blocks. Harold passes by, but stops just before he enters the off He looks at the tower, then the blocks.

dialogues.speaker: CHILD
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You're gonna have an extra block. Probably a red one. The kids just look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold sits in a small office lit by candles and Chinese lanterns across from an older man in a puffy sweater with his legs tucked under him in an office chair (DR. CAYLY). Behind their scene we can hear the sound of CHILDREN FIGH OVER BLOCKS.

dialogues.speaker: CAYLY
dialogues.text: I had a very interesting little "convo" with someone in your section.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: CAYLY
dialogues.text: They said you're feeling a little “wibbly-wobbly"...

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Uh...

dialogues.speaker: CAYLY
dialogues.text: Catch a little cubicle fever?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I don't know. I think I'm okay. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAYLY
dialogues.text: Harold: a tree doesn't think it's a tree. It is a tree. Harold stares blankly.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Why was Harold talking to this man? This man was an idiot. Harold looks up. Cayly speaks, but we can't hear him as t Narrator continues.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: This man used words like “wibbly- wobbly” and “convo” and explained that trees were trees. Of course trees were trees. Harold knew trees were trees. Who doesn't know that trees are trees. The camera begins to zoom in on the (concerned) face of Harold's watch.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: What Harold didn't know was why he couldn't shake the smell of brownies from his senses, why Ms. Pascal had made his fingertips quiver and lips go numb. And this man wasn't helping to explain that at all, nor anything at all really. Something had to change. Suddenly Harold's watch begins to BEEP. He's jolted back reality and Cayly stops talking. Harold looks at his watch. The face flashes blue, almost if sending a warning.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Sorry... my... that's... it's not supposed to be beeping. Sorry. Sorry. Harold quickly stops his watch. He looks at it. It looks back.

dialogues.speaker: CAYLY
dialogues.text: Harold?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Huh? Oh. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CAYLY
dialogues.text: What's going on, Harold?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I... Well. (pause) Nothing. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: {pause) Everything's fine. Cayly opens a file.

dialogues.speaker: CAYLY
dialogues.text: Listen, according to your record you haven't taken vacation for a few years now. How about you take a break. Use some of that “vaycay" time.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: ‘Yeah. Maybe that's a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: CAYLY
dialogues.text: Harold. I'm not really supposed to do this but... Cayly gets out of his chair and gives Harold a big hug.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Uh... Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: CAYLY
dialogues.text: Take some "me time", Harold. Maybe a bubble bath. Cayly winks.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Harold was nauseated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold comes out of Cayly's office and leaves the Human Resources offices. The camera. pans down to reveal the blocks built into a s of buildings on either side of a city street, one extra r block lying uselessly in the middle. The camera reveals a little Lego man in a black suit stan next to one of the buildings... until he's run over by a Lego bus handied by one of the toddlers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold stands at the bus stop next to several other COMMU He looks ready to go home, crawl into bed and possibly ne come out. He is so worn out, he doesn't notice Ana walkin up the sidewalk across the street. Harold's watch notices, as we reveal its (excited) face, Harold just stands there, staring reticently at the aspha Suddenly there is a BEEPING sound. A few people look arou even check their cell phones. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold looks at his watch; its blue face flashing as it B loudly and constantly. Everyone looks at Harold. Ana continues up the street. The watch keeps beeping at Harold.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Harold assumed his watch was simply on the fritz, and never even thought about what it was trying to tell him. Harold quickly presses a few buttons, but the watch will stop BEEPING nor flashing. Harold shakes his watch. He drops his briefcase to deal with the watch, but the BE only gets louder. Everyone begins to stare. Ana is almost gone.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: In fact, Harold had never once paid attention to his watch, other than to find out the time. And, honestly, it drove his watch crazy. Harold looks at the sky, shaking his head. Harold puts hi watch behind his back, to muffle the BEEPING.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And on this particular Wednesday evening, as Harold waited for the bus, his watch suddenly stopped... if out of nothing else but sheer frustration. But only for a brief moment, after which it immediately s BEEPING and flashes “Enter Time" Ana is gone. Harold neve saw her. Harold looks at his watch. He presses a button on the sid

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Uh... Does somebody happen to have the time?

dialogues.speaker: COMMUTER
dialogues.text: I've got 5:47. Harold quickly resets his watch to 5:47 and saves it.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: So Harold's watch thrust him onto the mercy of the immitigable path of fate. For as he reset the time of his watch, little did Harold know that this. simple, seemingly innocuous act would ultimately result in his death. The air is sucked out of Harold as he hears this. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What? He looks up. .Everyone looks. |

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What!? Hey! , (pause) Did you... Did you just... Did... You said it would ultimately result in my death!? ... It would... I'm sorry... Hello-- did you say in my death? . (pause) Hello?.~ Harold quickly tries to change the reading on the watch. Frantic, he is unable to get his fingers to work properly He looks up.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why? Why my death!? Hello! Why!? (pause) Talk to me!! But there is no response. Harold continues to yell into the sky but he is drowned o by the SCREECHING BRAKES of the bus, which comes to a sto directly in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold comes barreling into his living room, throws down briefcase and overcoat. He nearly trips over his ottoman.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Okay. Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold bursts into his bathroom and immediately grabs his toothbrush. He looks up, expecting to hear the voice. He puts toothpaste on it. He runs water. He begins brushi his teeth, and with each move he pauses in the hopes the voice will return.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Why won't you say anything!? He throws down his toothbrush.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I heard you. "...that would ultimately result in his death." I heard you!! He spits and storms out.  eu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold randomly begins grabbing things: Ties, lamps, pill ete. trying to elicit a response from the omniscient voic

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Come on you stupid voice! “Harold, frantic, picked up his lamp." {shakes the lamp) “Harold, incensed, shook the hell out of it for no apparent reason." Overcome with anguish he drops the lamp he's picked up.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "Upset, he dropped the stupid lamp!" "The lamp crashed to the ground and shattered into a hundred pieces..." "Harold stormed to his closet!" Something! (pause)

dialogues.speaker: SAY SOMETHING
dialogues.text: He collapses against his bed.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "Harold, distraught, began to just..." (pause) "Harold, distraught, could not..." (pause) "Harold, distraught...” Blackout. The following appears on screen: "IT don't get an answer except 011 011 01..." -~ Sleater-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold sits across from a thin, very old woman in bifocal DR. MITTAG-LEFFLER, in a large and upscale office. He see uncomfortable on the long, leather sofa, sitting at the f end with his legs folded and arms crossed.

dialogues.speaker: MITTAG-LEFFLER
dialogues.text: So you're here, not because you heard voices, but because you stopped hearing voices.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I... I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: MITTAG-LEFFLER
dialogues.text: I'm afraid what you're describing is schizophrenia.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No. No. It's not schizophrenia. It's just a voice in my head. I mean... I mean, the voice isn't telling me to do anything, it's telling me what I've already done. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes 26.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Accurately, and with a better vocabulary.

dialogues.speaker: MITTAG-LEFFLER
dialogues.text: Mr. Crick, you have a voice speaking to you.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No. Not tome. About me. I am somehow inextricably involved in some type of story. I'm like a character in my own life. But... see the problem is that the voice comes and goes, like there are other parts of the story not being told to me ahd I need to know what those other parts are before it‘s too late.

dialogues.speaker: MITTAG-LEFFLER
dialogues.text: Before the story concludes... with your death.

dialogues.speaker: , HAROLD
dialogues.text: Yes. her head.

dialogues.speaker: MITTAG-LEFFLER
dialogues.text: Mr. Crick, I hate to sound like a broken record, but that's schizophrenia.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You don't sound like a broken record, it's just not schizophrenia. She just looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. What if what I said was true. What if, please... just, hypothetically. If I was part of a story... a narrative, even only in my own mind... (pause) What would you suggest I do?

dialogues.speaker: MITTAG-LEFFLER
dialogues.text: I would suggest you take prescribed medication.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Other than that.

dialogues.speaker: MITTAG-LEFFLER
dialogues.text: I don't know... I would... I'd have you speak to someone who knows about literature... I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Okay. Thanks. Thank you. That's... yes. That's a good idea. He stands.

dialogues.speaker: MITTAG-LEFFLER
dialogues.text: But please Mr. Crick, if the voice tells you to quit your job... or move into a refrigerator box... or make any unusually large weapon purchases... please call me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold sits in his cubicle, scouring through information online. He rubs his eyes. He clicks on a link. A new window opens to reveal a picture of a man behind a desk in an office filled with books. Harold scans the web page, coming across text that reads something to the effe of, "Literary Dean Emeritus: Professor Jules Hilbert." He clicks on the name. A new photograph is revealed of Hilbert conducting a seminar. The caption reads: "Profess Hilbert in his most popular course: The Entire History of Everything Literate. Harold scans the caption. His fingers stop on the name, “Professor Hilbert."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The campus is situated in the middle of the city: several tall buildings situated around a common area: a smaller, more metropolitan version of a quad. Harold consults a folded piece of yellow paper trying to are what it says to the series of large, imposing buildings around him. » There are several COEDS studying, playing catch and relax on the lawns. An OLDER MAN stands upright, holding an old beat up pair of glasses a couple feet below him, apparent using them to read a book that lies open at his feet. Harold continues a few steps before stopping a passing STUDENT.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Excuse me... Hi. Can you tell me where The Erdos Offices are?

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: Sure. They're right back over there behind that big brick building. Hey are you the new econ professor?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No. Why would you-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: Listen, how hard's your class. I need an easy A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I don't...

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: Is showing up mandatory?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (pause) No. Come whenever you like. Bring beer. Where are the Erdos Offices, again? JI have a meeting with Professor Hilbert.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: Oh. He's not in The Erdos Offices.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: He's not?

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: No. He's standing with his glasses out right next to that oak tree. Harold turns.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: See you in class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold is led down a long, dark corridor with rows of off on either side by PROFESSOR HILBERT, a short, older man w speeds down the hall at a clipped pace, one arm through o sleeve of a tweed jacket holding a cup of coffee, the oth out of the jacket holding the book he was reading.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: So you're the young gentleman who called me about the narrator?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Says you're gonna die.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Uh... yes.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. How long has it given you to live?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I don't know. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professor Hilbert stops and looks squarely at Harold.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Dramatic irony. It'll fuck you every time. He pats Harold on the shoulder than leads him into an off INT. HILBERT’S OFFICE -- CONTINUOUS Hilbert's office is quite the same as the photograph and matches him perfectly: There are books everywhere except the bookshelves, various laterai-thinking puzzles are str about (almost all solved) and several rolled up carpets inexplicably lean in the corner. A currently brewing coff maker sits on the windowsill.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Please. Recline. Hilbert offers Harold the couch which is covered in books Harold finds a six inch space and sits. Hilbert tosses ou his coffee and pours himself another cup.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Coffee?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Uh... no. No thank you.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Sure?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: So, you're crazy or what?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Well--

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Are you allowed to say that to crazy people?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Oh well. How many tiles in the hallway out there?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: You were counting them as we walked weren't you?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Of course. What bank do you work at?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No bank. IRS Auditor.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Live alone?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: . PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Any pets?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No. If we could just--

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR, HILBERT
dialogues.text: Friends?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No. Well. Dave. At work.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: I see. The narrator. Exactly what does he sound like?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: It's... it's a woman.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Huh. Is it a familiar woman? Someone you know?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: But this woman told you you're going to die?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Well, she didn't tell me, she told--

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: But you believed her.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Well... She'd been right about a few other things.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Such as?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: How I felt about work.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: You hate your work. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Well. Not the most insightful voice in the world is it... Ist thing on a list of what American's say they hate? Work. 2nd? Traffic. 3rd? Missing socks. See what I'm saying?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Sort of.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: I told you you were going to die, you believe me?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: tT don't know you.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: But you don't know this narrator either.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Well... Hilbert swallows the rest of his coffee in one gulp and g to refill his cup.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Okay, Mr. Crick. I can't help you.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not an expert in crazy. I'm an expert in literature and I gotta tell you, thus far there’s not a single literary thing about you.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: I don‘t doubt you hear a voice, but it couldn't possibly be a narrator because frankly there doesn't seem to be much to narrate. Besides that, this semester I'm teaching five courses, mentoring two doctorate candidates and I'm the faculty lifeguard at the pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (devastated) Oh. I... I just, I thought you--

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: {feeling sorry for him.) Perhaps you should keep a journal, write down what she's said to you or something.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I can barely remember it all. I ‘just remember, "Little did he know that this single, seemingly innocuous event. would lead to his death."

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: (overlapping) [Aaah... I'11 tell you... Hawaiian coffee is simply~-} What?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: "Little did he know this--"

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Did you say, "Little did he know?"

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Dear God. I've written papers on “Little did he know..." I nearly taught a course on "Little did he know..." Harold shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: --Sonofabitch. Harold, “little did he know" means there's something he doesn't know. That means there’s something you don't know. That's... Christ... the voice is literally in 3rd person. Did you know that?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No. I didn't know that. I also don't know what "innocuous" means.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Harold. I want you to come back on Tuesday. No. You could be dead by Tuesday. Come back tomorrow. At 1:30.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Five seconds ago you said you wouldn't help me.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: It's been a very revealing five seconds, Harold.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: {pause) Okay. (pause. reassured) Okay. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Good. Good. Listen. If the voice returns, don't resist it. But don't provoke it. And it's probably wise to avoid starting sentences with "This is the last time I dot dot dot"... Hilbert winks at him.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll see you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold sits alone in a seat towards the back of the bus. stares out at the sleek city as it passes by his window. seems deep in thought.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Harold was deep in thought... Harold looks up at the voice quickly. He then rummages to find a legal pad and a pen and begins transcribing the narration as best as he can.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For a few brief moments, from Born Boulevard to Euclid Ave., all the calculations and all the time and all the precision of Harold's life just faded away. The bus comes to a stop and PASSENGERS get off and come o

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How perfect then, that in this space, Ana Pascal would appear. He quickly looks to see Ana Pascal walking up the aisle towards him. She sees him and immediately turns around an starts to walk back towards the front of the bus.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Ms. Pascal! (pause) Ms. Pascal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can't move forward any further as a VERY LARGE MAN is standing in her way. She's stuck.

dialogues.speaker: . HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ms. Pascal, it's me... Harold Crick... from the IRS! She turns around. In fact, everyone turns around.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (indicating the several empty ones) Hi... would you like a seat?

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: There's eleven open ones.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: I don't care. The bus starts moving forward, propelling her towards the back. Off balance, she just sits down across the aisle fr Harold. They look at each other uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Lousy. I'm being audited.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Oh. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: By a real creep too.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Oh. They sit, awkwardly and silently.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Uh... I think I owe you an apology.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Well... IRS auditors are given rigorous aptitude tests before we can begin work... We're tested on arithmetic, number theory, memory, (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: cognitive skills, synthesis... the whole gamut... (pause) Unfortunately for you, we aren't tested on tact or good manners. {pause} So... I apologize I... uh... ogled you. Ana thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Apology accepted. But only because you stammered. They smile at each other. Harold's watch looks on (happily).

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Harold nervously made small talk.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: So, you're a frequenter of the metropolitan transit authority too?

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Very small talk.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: No. I'm just late.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Ah... big flag burning to get to?

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: My weekly evil conspiracy and needlepoint group. Would you like to come along?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No. I left all my thimbles and socialist reading material at home. She laughs. A real laugh. The kind you get from people wh actually like you.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You uh... you... have... uh... very... straight teeth.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Thanks. They're real.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Harold quickly calculated the odds of making an ass of himself in ratio to the amount of time he stayed to chat.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Actually I should go. This is my stop. The side door opens and he hops out. She smiles to hersel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold steps down, somewhat relieved that the conversatio was not a total travesty.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Harold was elated and surprised by ,his somewhat flirtatious encounter with Ms. Pascal. Harold beams: upward.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So elated he exited. the Transit Authority Bus a good 27 blocks too early and would now have to walk. He looks around. His shoulders sag.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Goddamnit, couldn't you tell me that earlier? [Sonofabitch.} He begins to walk down the street. Bad Religion's "Strang Than Fiction" begins (track 3 on your cd).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAROLD brushes his teeth in his mint colored bathroom, st counting brush strokes but slightly less emphatically. Hi wristwatch looks on from the nightstand in a close up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold crawls into bed, gently removing his wristwatch an placing it on the nightstand next to him. He presses a fe of its buttons to set its alarm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold, peach between his teeth, hurries towards the bus stop while putting on his black overcoat and carrying a briefcase. He counts his steps coming to a precise halt a he reaches the stop, his lips moving slightly to himself. He looks. The bus is just now approaching. He made it wit plenty of time. His watch (smugly) peers up at him. The music fades...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professor Hilbert, a book open in his hands, opens his do and lets Harold in, The office is much the same. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain taps on the window with wet fingertips.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Mr. Crick, come in come in... Please. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I'm... I'm alright actually.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Good. Great. Count the tiles outside?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (lying) No.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: (also lying} Of course not. He jumps from his seat grabs a notebook and pen and a pai of bifocals. He quickly pours himself a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've devised a test-~- how exciting is that!-- with around 23 questions that I think might help uncover more truths about this narrator. Now, these may seem silly, but your candor is paramount.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Okay. Agreed. He places the notebook on the desk in front of him and ho out his glasses.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Good. So... we know it's a woman's voice, the story involves your death, it's modern, it's in English and I'm assuming the author has a cursory knowledge of the city.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Good. Okay, question 1: Has anyone recently left any gifts outside your home... anything: gum, money... a large wooden horse?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Harold, just answer the question.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Uh... no. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wus Hilbert writes down the answer but does not stop.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Good. Do you find yourself inclined . te solve murder mysteries in large, luxurious homes to which you may or May not have been invited?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No. Listen--

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Okay. On a scale of one to ten, what would you consider to be the ‘likelihood you might be assassinated.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Assassinated?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: One being very unlikely, ten being expecting it at every corner.

dialogues.speaker: . HAROLD
dialogues.text: I don't... I...

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Perhaps, let me re-phrase this. Are you the King of anything?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Anything. King of the Lanes at the local bowling alley.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: King of the Lanes?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: King of the Lanes? King of the Trolls? A clandestine land found underneath your floorboards? Anything?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No. That's ridiculous--

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Agreed. But let's start at ridiculous and move backwards. Now... was any part of you now at one time part of something else.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Like, do I have someone else's arms?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Well, is it possible that you were at one time made of stone, wood, lye, varied corpse parts or earth made holy by rabbinical elders? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No. No. That’s. No... I'm sorry, what do these questions have to do with anything?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Nothing. That's the point.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Harold. The only way to find out what story you're in is to determine what stories you're not in. Odd as it may seem, I've just ruled out half of Greek literature, seven fairy tales, ten Chinese fables, and determined conclusively you are not King Hamlet, Scout Finch, Ms. Marple, Frankenstein's monster or a golem. (pause) Aren't you relieved to know you're not a golem?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I... I guess.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Good. Then just answer the questions... A SCREECH of tires and suddenly And You Will Know Us By T Trail of Dead (track 4 on your cd) begins to play...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To avoid the young blonde boy on his new bicycle, an SUV with Kay inside is now spinning out of control across the wet surface of a rainy intersection. The SUV hops the curb, heading directly towards a boutiqu shoe store. CUSTOMERS and EMPLOYEES (including the middle-aged black woman, now in an employee's uniform of khakis, white shir with a name tag) dive out of the way as the SUV crashes violently through the front display window and into the s the impact thrusting Kay to crash through her windshield. The SUV sends shoes and glass everywhere and comes to a h in the middle of the store. People rush from outside towards the store. Some just sta in shock. The young boy rides his bicycle, disappearing behind a co Rain pours over the gash in the window, jagged shards of glass framing the destroyed SUV and Kay's corpse on its h surrounded by scattered shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From behind a pile, the middle-aged black woman rises, un and relieved to be alive. With the single note of the vio We...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the street sits Kay on a bus stop bench, staring a the street and smoking. She just shakes her head and disp of her cigarette in her bizarre, disgusting manner. Next her is Penny, holding an umbrella. Both stare at the shoe store, which is completely intact.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Kay. May I ask what we're doing out here?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: We're imagining car wrecks.

dialogues.speaker: . PENNY
dialogues.text: I see. And we can't imagine them inside?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: No. Did you know 41% of accidents in this city occur in times of inclement weather?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: So do 90% of pneumonia cases.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Really? Pneumonia. That's an interesting way to die. But how would Harold catch pneumonia? Besides, it takes forever to kill someone with pneumonia. Even if he caught it in Chapter 10, he wouldn't finally keel over until Chapter 17 at least. Penny shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Kay. Have you actually written today?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I'd like you to write at least a page upon our return to the office.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Fine. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: And I would be remiss not to remind you that the publishers expect to See something soon.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: They can see my ass. She hacks a terrible cough. Penny puils a pamphlet out of her jacket pocket and hands it to Kay.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Literature on the nicotine patch program.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (coyly) Penny. You should just take up smoking. It's much more enjoyable. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We catch back up with Hilbert and Harold as they finish t quiz.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Okay. We're almost done, Harold. Just a few more. (pause) Do you subscribe to any belief system?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Is math a belief system?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Good. I believe in math.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Alright. What's your most favorite word?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (pause) Integer.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Good. Good. Do you aspire to anything: conquer Russia, win a whistling contest... anything?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Uh... no. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Harold. You must have some ambition.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD ,
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Some underlying dream...? Think Harold.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Uh... I've always wanted my life to be more musical. ve PROFESSOR HILBERT Like West Side Story?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No... like, well... (pause) . I've always wanted to learn to play the guitar.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Okay. That counts. Good. Very good. {pause) Last one: What's your secret? Harold looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: My secret? ‘

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Yes. What is it about you that no one but you knows? Harold thinks for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Well... (pause) I count things.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Harold. That's not a secret. It's absolutely obvious you count things. Why do you count things? Harold takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I don't know. Sometimes, if I feel a little strange, it just makes me feel better. They share a look between them. Hilbert nods.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Okay. We're done. Excellent. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: to.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think the next step is to determine conclusively if you're in a comedy or a tragedy. To quote Italo Calvino, "The ultimate meaning to which all stories refer has two faces: the continuity of life, the inevitability of death.”

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: {pause} What?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Tragedy you die. Comedy you get hitched.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: {facetiously) Oh. Great.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I haven't even been on a date in three years.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Well... most comic heroes fall in love with people who are introduced after the story has begun, usually people who hate the hero initially, although I can't imagine anyone hating you.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Professor Hilbert. I'm an auditor. Nobody likes me.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Not dislikes you. Hates you. Detests you. Loathes the very core of you. Anybody like that? Harold thinks.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: There's somebody who I just met who I know really really doesn't like me.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Well, that sounds like a comedy... try to develop that plot.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: There's no real approach. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Except... well, if push comes to shove... ask her to talk about the past. Harold looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Uh-oh. I don't want to be late. Harold gets up and begins to leave.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Alright. Take care. Call me if the ‘plot twists. :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold comes into the bakery carrying not only his briefc but his pad of paper and a pen. The bakery is not as busy as before but still bustles. The homeless man is back wit his dog. Harold sees Ana behind the counter. He waves. She doesn't. Harold makes a mark in his pad. He comes to the side of t counter where Ana meets him.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Morning, Mr. Crick.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Morning. Harold makes another mark in his pad.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: You're here early. Must have a lot of people to extort. He forces a laugh, smiles and makes another mark.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No. No. Just you. Actually, it should only take me the day to make sure the 27% is all you owe.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: I won't be paying, no matter the percent, Mr. Crick.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I know. But the percent determines how big your cell is. He chuckles. She doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And... you can call me Harold.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: I know. I don't want to. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Oh. He makes another mark in his pad. She notices.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: What are you marking?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Oh. This? Uh... Nothing. Nothing. He holds it close to himself to hide it from her.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why don't we start with your tax files from the previous four years.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Sure. She gives him a coy smile and lifts the counter top so he may pass through.

dialogues.speaker: ANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This way. She leads him towards the back. He loosens his grip on his pad. A close look reveals that he's made two columns: Comedy a Tragedy. He's been marking those things that lean towards each, respectively. It's currently two to two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold sits down at a desk and is presented with a large full of loose papers.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: My files.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: My tax files.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: In this box?

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I wasn't informed they had to be presented in an organized fashion.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You keep your tax files like this? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: No. Actually I'm very fastidious about my filing. I put them in this box just to fuck with you. The Hives' "Knock Knock" begins to play (track 5 on your cd).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold takes off his coat and rolls up his sleeves. Ana helps customers out in the bakery. Harold can't make heads or tails of the papers. Harold very kindly confronts Ana about a few figures, onl to have her ignore him. Harold marks his pad. He checks his watch: 1:00 pm Harold comes out of the office and stretches. As Ana pass he tries to strike up a conversation. She just walks righ past him. He shakes his head. He marks his pad. Harold comes out the back door of the bakery, carrying a paper sack lunch and his pad. He approaches Ana who sits the break bench eating. Harold sits next to her and she quickly tosses out her sandwich and goes inside. Harold opens up his pad. Ana struggles with a hot cookie sheet. Harold tries to he by taking it from her but isn't wearing oven mitts and bu his fingers. Ana suggests that maybe he return to his work. Harold marks his pad. Harold shakes his fists in frustration at the work. Harold hangs his head, exhausted. Harold finishes his work. He rubs his eyes and checks his watch. It's 8:30 pm. The music fades...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bakery has shut down for the evening save for a small area of the kitchen where Ana is transferring cookies fro sheet to a cooling rack. There are only a few lights on a Ana works silently and peacefully. Harold comes out of the office, exhausted, carrying his briefcase, jacket and pad. He stands for a moment and wat her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: (pause) Hi.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: {pause} Hi.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: (pause) Everyone's gone.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: {pause} I know.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: {pause) I made too much batter so I'm baking off some cookies.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (pause. looks around.) Where did all the other food go?

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Well, we try to only make what we think we'll sell. The smail_ amount left over we give to the shelter up the street.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Ah... well... goodnight. He goes to leave. She looks after him.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Want a cookie? Harold stops, and thinks, but he's given up.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Uh... No.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Come on. They're warm and gooey, fresh out of the oven...

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No. I don't like cookies.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: You don't like cookies?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: (pause) What the fuck is wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I... I don't...

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Everybody likes cookies.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I just--

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: After. a really awful, no good day, didn't your mother ever give you milk and cookies?

dialogues.speaker: / HAROLD
dialogues.text: No. My mother couldn't bake. All the cookies I ever had were store bought.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: What about birthday cakes?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Store bought.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Breakfast muffins?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Store bought. Frozen. Thawed in the oven. ANA ° Bake sale brownies?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Private school. No bake sales.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: (pause. sincerely) That's probably what turned you into an evil government drone.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No. Actually, I was kidnapped by gypsy accountants as a teenager. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Really. A nomadic tribe of abacus builders. It's that same laugh. The wonderful, human, loving one fr the bus. Suddenly she stops and looks at him. They stare at each other for a moment. Her lips part. His fingers twitch. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ay. Harold's watch looks on (anxiously). The pad of paper reveals their lopsided fate: comedy 7, tragedy 114. Harold's watch waits. Then...

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: {ordering} Okay. Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Listen, I should be...

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: No. Sit down. He sits on a stool across the butcher block from her. She goes to a cupboard and pulls out a glass and a plate. She goes to the refrigerator and pulls out a bottle of milk, then pours some into the glass. She brings the glass and plate over to the block, places a single cookie on the pl and places the plate in front of Harold.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Thank you. I...

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Eat the cookie.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I really--

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Eat the cookie.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Ms. Pascal-—

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: (sweetly) It was a really awful, no good day. I know. I made sure of it. So pick up the cookie, dip it in the goddamn milk and eat the fucking thing. She slides the plate closer to him. He cautiously takes a cookie, dunks it and bites into it. His eyes light up, his shoulders relax, he breathes.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Wow... that's... that's a... really good cookie. Once again she suddenly stops and looks at him. They star at each other for a moment. Her lips part. His fingers twitch. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ou. Harold's watch looks on (anxiously}. The pad of paper reveals their lopsided fate. Harold's watch waits. Then..: She takes the plate and goes to get him more cookies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. (pause) When did you decide to become a baker?

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Oh. In college.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Oh. Like, "cooking college?"

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: No. I went to Harvard Law.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Oh. Oh. Geez. I-- sorry. I just assumed... Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: No. It's alright. I didn't finish. T uh... uh... She brings a plate with more cookies to Harold.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Did something happen?

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Not really. I was... I was barely accepted. I mean, barely. The only reason they let me come was because of my essay. How I was going to make the world a better place with my degree. And I went there thinking... well, I went thinking that I might make a difference and uh... well... Harvard Law has the smartest people in the world, people who will one day shape the earth, and it’s competitive and vicious and exhausting... And I'd have to participate in these study sessions, classmates and I, all night long. Sometimes for a couple days straight. And so... She trails off, staring into space again, unsure whether proceed, Once again she suddenly stops and looks at him. They star at each other for a moment. Her lips part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Si. His fingers twitch. Harold's watch looks on (anxiously). The pad of paper reveals their lopsided fate. Harold's watch waits. Then... Gently, Harold pushes the plate of cookies across to her. She looks at him, then at the plate. She sits down, picks up a cookie, then continues...

dialogues.speaker: ANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And so I would bake-- cookies usually-- so no one would go hungry while we worked. I'd bake all afternoon in the kitchen in the dorm before a big study session and write down what I was doing in one of those black Mead Journals they sell by the gross in the Campus Bookstore, And I'd bring my little treats to the study groups... and people loved them. Oatmeal Cookies. Peanut Butter Bars. Chocolate Chip and Macadamia Nut Wedges. And everyone would eat and stay happy and study harder and do better on the tests and more people would come to the study groups and the study groups got better and I would make more snacks and try to find better recipes and the results would always get better and better and soon it was Cheese and Apricot Croissants and Mocha Bars with Almond Glaze and Lemon Chiffon Cakes with Zesty Peach icing and our study groups were famous around all of Cambridge: not because we had the most copious notes, or the smartest people, but because we had the best snacks... She gets up and goes to the cookie sheet and begins to re the cookies and put them on a large paper plate. She yank a strip of plastic wrap from a tube and wraps the larger plate of cookies.

dialogues.speaker: ANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And at the end of the spring term... I had 27 study partners, eight black Mead journals filled with recipes... and a D average. (pause) So I dropped out. Simply, without alarm, and without any regrets. {pause) I just figured, if I was gonna make the world a better place... I'd do it with cookies. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold stares at her, obviously enamored. She looks at hi plate. There's only one cookie left.

dialogues.speaker: ANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘ I'm glad you liked them.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Iouh... I did. Thank you for forcing me to eat them.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: You're welcome. They look at each other for a moment. Harold finds himsel suddenly nervous. He looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I should go. Thank you. Thanks again. I mean. For the cookies. She takes a moment, then she offers the larger plate.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Why don't you take them?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: "No?"

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No. Really.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: I... Are you...

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Oh. (slightly hurt) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I mean. I... I would but, uh... I can't,

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: You can't.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: It... See, it constitutes a gift and we're not allowed to...

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I shouldn't have even had the other ones. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: I'm not going to tell anyone.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I know. But if you did, I could--

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: I'm not going to--

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I know, but if you did-- I could... (pause) Tell you what, I'll purchase them...

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: What? No. That's... no... nevermind. Go home.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I could...

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: No. That... that... [totally defeats the purpose]. No. Go home.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: But I really--

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Go home. He stops. He gets his coat, picks up his briefcase and he for the door. He suddenly realizes and turns around.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (pause) You baked those cookies for me didn't you? Embarrassed, she simply shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You were trying to be nice to me and I totally blew it... She shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And that may very well be the last time you try to be nice again... She looks at him... and then, once more, shrugs. He hangs his head. He pulls out his pad and his pen. He opens the pad and makes one last mark.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know this'll just sound like gibberish to you... (pause) .»..but I think I'm in a tragedy. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pause) And if I am... it's no one's fault but my own. He turns and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold walks down the sidewalk, the lights of the city pl against all the glass and steel.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Perhaps, to say Harold Crick did not give enough credit to fate is similar to saying that he did not give enough credit to major locomotive train accidents. As anyone else could explain, the precision with which fate must work in order to cause two trains to exist on the same track at the same time, in spite of all the technology and human resources is absolutely remarkable and unlike any phenomena of the modern world. Harold has a seat at the bus stop, the homeless man and h dog sitting next to him.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Harold's death was quickly approaching... and he still remained completely oblivious to the moment when his, Carla's and the boy on the bicycle's courses would smash into each other. Here he was. Alone. Ms. Pascal blocks away, walking in the opposite direction. Harold writes down the name "Carla".

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Fate, like two careening locomotives, would occur with or without his participation. And the miraculous mathematics of this remained inconceivable for even a true calculator such as Harold. He writes down "boy on bicycle". He sighs.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Harold could not understand fate. He could not understand the behavior of his watch. He could not even understand the desires of his own heart. So he certainly couldn't understand the poetry of train wrecks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A locker closes, revealing Professor Hilbert.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Well the first thing is don't get on any trains. Harold stands in a suit, carrying a briefcase next to OTH SWIMMERS who dry off from the showers. We can see that Professor Hilbert is wearing a neon green Speedo cap, wit orange goggles and a pair of really tight purple Speedo shorts. Hilbert. locks a combination lock and tosses a to around his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Any idea who "Carla" and "the boy on the bicycle" are?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I think they're other characters.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Maybe. Maybe. Fantastic. They begin to walk past the lockers and around a corner. Past the coach's office where Hilbert takes a whistle off hook.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Professor Hilbert, please. I totally failed at the comic hero thing. In fact, I think she likes me even less.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: I know. It's great.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What? They walk towards a set of doors, behind which we hear wa and giggling.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: You proved something else entirely. The voice seems to be dependent on actions you take. You say the voice arrives when you do certain things, then stops when you don't do those things. It may be that you yourself are perpetuating this story.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: So I suggest we try something else.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What about Ms. Pascal? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Forget her.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Forget her? Other than numbers she's all I think about.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Harold, if you want to stay alive, you have to try something else.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Try what?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Nothing?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: See... some plots are moved forward by external events or crisis... others are moved forward by the characters themselves. He points to the door.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If I go through that door that plot continues. The story of me through the door. If I stay here... that plot can't move forward, the story ends. (pause) Also, if I stay here, I'm late. Hilbert goes through the door. Harold follows.

dialogues.speaker: INT, SWIMMING POOL -
dialogues.text: Several faculty members use the pool, most of whom in ter swim attire. None of them pay any attention to Harold or Hilbert.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Harold. Don't do anything tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Stay home. Don't answer the phone. Don't open the door. Don't brush your teeth.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What about work?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Call them tonight. Tell them you're not coming. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Don't go to work!?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Don't do anything that may move the plot forward. Instead, let's see if the pilot finds you. He puts his nose plugs in and climbs up to the lifeguard' chair. Harold is left standing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold turns down his sheets, about to climb into bed. He starts to take his watch off but stops. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The area immediately surrounding the couch has been transformed into a makeshift campground: a cooler rests a one end of the couch, a bowl full of water rests on the c table next to a bar of soap and a hand towel, and bags of beef jerky and chips are piled on the floor next to couch Harold tosses a pillow down on the couch as a final touch He takes his watch off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold's watch, at rest next to the hand towel, displays and begins to BEEP. Harold appears from underneath a blan on the couch, already dressed. He turns off the beeping without looking at his watch. He sits up and looks at the television, which is already He shifts as he realizes he has to pee. He sighs, then reaches underneath his coffee table to pul out a tupperware jar. The camera respectfully looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold continues to sit in the middle of the couch, watch television. The glow from the television quickly changes.

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION
dialogues.text: She's a robot! She's a girl! She's a barrel of laughs! Coming up next: four hours of “Small Wonder" back to back to back as part of our Super Eighties Marathon! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold picks up the remote to change the channel but remembers. He puts the remote down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold munches on packaged popcorn and watches the televi vapidly. The phone RINGS. - Harold looks at the phone. It RINGS ag He just stares at it. It RINGS again. He looks at the television then back at the telephone, longingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold is virtually comatose.

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION
dialogues.text: Awwww... that was the last episode of “Small Wonder" for today... Harold's eyes pop open. He looks’ at the television excit

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But don't worry, we have three full hours of MR. BELVEDERE!!! Harold's face drops. The phone RINGS again. Harold sinks his head into his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold stares at the television, the sun setting behind i There is a SOUND at the door. Harold turns to look. The mail slot opens and several different sized pieces of mail come through the door and plop onto Harold's floor. The phone RINGS, Harold's face twinges with frustration. The phone RINGS again. The t.v. audience laughs. Suddenly Harold's watch begins to BEEP. Harold, shocked, goes to shut it off but stops. A shadow quickly descends over the apartment and a large CREAKING sound can be heard. Harold sees something out of the corner of his eye. He turns. Harold's POV: Outside his bay window, behind the televisi quickly approaches a wrecking ball, headed straight for t back of Mr. Belvedere's head and the rest of Harold's apartment. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold is just able to grab his watch and jump over the of his couch before the wrecking ball SHATTERS the front Harold's apartment with a tremendous CRASH. Glass and debris are sent flying into the room as the wal crumble around the enormous ball... which stops short of couch at the end of its swing. Harold remains crouched behind his couch, until he hears large CREAKING of the wrecking ball retreating. He peeks over the back. Although his couch remains intact and unmoved, the rest o Harold's living room is now a gaping hole. Harold slowly stands and can see a large crane with a wrecking ball on street two stories below. He walks towards the edge of his apartment. A large CREW OF PEOPLE in hardhats stand in the street surveying the wreckage.

dialogues.speaker: HEY
dialogues.text: At first no one notices.

dialogues.speaker: HEY
dialogues.text: He shakes his arms at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FOREMAN and a few members of the crew look up. On the third story of a partially demolished brownstone s Harold, yelling from the precipice of his apartment.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Holy crapping hell!

dialogues.speaker: CREW MEMBER
dialogues.text: Who the hell is that?

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Stop the crane-- Stop the crane}!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Foreman walks over to the sidewalk underneath Harold' apartment.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Hey! What are you doing!?

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Us? What are you doing? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Well, I was watching Mr. Belvedere!

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: ‘We're demolishing this place!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I noticed!

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: (looking in) Is that... Is that a couch? HAROLD . Yes itts a couch. It's my couch!

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Well what is your couch doing in there?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I live here, Stupid! This is where I keep my stuff. My name's on the goddamn buzzer! “Harold Crick. Apartment 3B. 1893 McCarthy.” The Foreman pauses momentarily.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Did you say Eighteen Ninety Three McCarthy?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Yes. The foreman looks at his pad.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Oh. (pause) Woops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professor Hilbert addresses his class until he is interru by Harold who just barges in. Harold is a complete mess and carries two suit cases on e side of him.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: So... I was doing nothing, like you said... and then... a wrecking ball came flying into my apartment.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Holy crapping hell. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: It was... I'm not exactly sure it was plot... I was hoping you'd just say it was a very bad coincidence.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Meeting an insurance agent the day your policy runs out is coincidence. Getting a letter from the Emperor saying he's visiting is plot. (pause) A wrecking ball... is something else entirely. Hilbert's class writes this down emphatically. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold and Professor Hilbert stand in the hallways, conti their conversation. Hilbert takes a big, deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: (pause) You don't control your fate, Harold.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: {audibly despondent) I know.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: It's... Harold... let's: This is a last ditch effort but it's possible, I mean-- do you still have the journal of things the narrator says?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Well, it's possible, through analysis of sentence structure and some extensive vernacular profiling, I could conceivably figure out who's writing this story.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: And then what?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: And maybe, possibly, you could ask her to stop... but I can't make any guarantees.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I'll help you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: No. You-- Harold. {pause} You were right. This narrator might very well kill you.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: So, can't we... can't we...

dialogues.speaker: . PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: So, I humbly suggest that you forget this and just go live your life. . HAROLD . Go live my life? I am living my life... I'd like to continue living my life.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Of course. I know. But I mean all of it. However long you have left... you can, Harold, you can use it to have an adventure, or discover something, or, or, or finish reading Crime and Punishment... hell, Harold, you could just eat nothing but pancakes if you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What's wrong with you? I don't want to eat nothing but pancakes, I want to live. Who, in their right mind, in a choice between pancakes and living, chooses pancakes?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Harold, if you'd pause to think I believe you'd realize that that answer is inextricably contingent upon the type of life being led. {pause) And, of course, the quality of the pancakes. They look at each other. Harold opens his case and hands Professor Hilbert his pad.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you understand what I'm saying?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Yes. I do. But you have to understand that this isn't a philosophy, or a literary theory, or a story to me. It's my life.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Absolutely. So go make it the one you've always wanted. This finally lands with Harold.  63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold stands on the sidewalk, still carrying his suitcas looking across the street. Ana is inside the bakery. She looks lovely and smiles as she hands the HOMELESS MAN a sandwich and gives his dog s water. Harold just takes a hefty sigh. He looks up, as if asking the voice for guidance. None comes. Harold watch looks on (hopefully) . But Harold just turns and walks up the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave opens the door to his guest bedroom, a small room dedicated exclusively to Battlestar Galactica paraphernal including posters, models of the ships and dozens of life sized cardboard cut-outs of the characters all standing i group, facing the bed. Harold looks at the room, trying t hide his fear and repulsion.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Here's your room. Or as I like to call it: Sleep Pod 2. Harold enters and puts down his suitcases.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Thanks, Dave.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: No problem, Dude. It'll be nice having you around. How long are you planning on staying again?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (pause) Well... I'm not sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold and Dave sit across from each other at the IKEA di room table, eating. Harold looks through a calculator cat as Dave works on several audits. Harold puts the catalog down.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Dave. Can I pose a somewhat abstract, purely hypothetical question?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thinks. 64.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: If you knew that you were going to die. Possibly soon. What would you do? . :

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Huh. I don't know. Am I the richest man-in the world?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No. You're you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Huh. Do I have a super power?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No. You're you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I know. I'mme. But do I have a super power?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No. Why would you have a super power?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I don't know, you said it was hypothetical.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Fine. Yes. You're really good at math. ©

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: That's not a power. That's a skill.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Dave-- You're good at math and you're invisible. There.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Easy. I'd go to space camp.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Space camp?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: In Texas. Where kids go and learn how to become astronauts. I've always wanted to go. Since I was nine.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You're invisible and you'd go to space camp?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I didn't pick invisible. You picked invisible.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Aren't you too old to go to space camp?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: You're never too old to go to space camp, Dude.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No, I mean... {forget it] nevermind. Harold looks at Dave, who resumes working.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Think you'll ever go?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Space Camp? Not with my volume of audits.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Auditor of the Year?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: All mine, Baby. All mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold stands in front of the mirror, brushing his teeth precisely before bed...
He stops for a moment, thinking. Then resumes.

He stops again and looks at his toothbrush. He takes a fe deep breaths... Then suddenly begins brushing his teeth with random, vari strokes. He stops and spits, then looks at himself in the mirror, invigorated.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Space Camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold stands in the electric guitar section of a large corporate music store, staring at the rows of guitars tha hang in front of him. The Narrator begins to speak. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.Q.)
dialogues.text: 122 guitars. 732 strings. 257 pickups. 189 volume nobs. Here Harold stood, face to face with his oldest desire... and stand is almost all Harold did. Harold looks up at the voice. He shakes his head, then tu to look at some of the guitars that hang to his right.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: It wasn't just about finding a guitar... it was about finding a .guitar that said something about Harold... Harold picks. up and inspects a black Les Paul guitar wit rose emblazoned on its body.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Unfortunately this guitar said, "When I get back to Georgia, that woman gonna feel my pain." Harold puts it back. He touches a Flying V shaped Peavey painted silver.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This one said something along the lines of, "Why yes, these pants are lycra." Harold walks a few steps and stops at an acoustic guitar.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "I'm very sensitive, very caring and I have absolutely no idea how to play the guitar.” Harold eyes a totally tricked out Double Neck Gibson 8G w a pickup toggle, various knobs, a whammy bar and a pictur of a dragon airbrushed on its facade.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "I'm compensating for something. Guess what." Slightly exasperated, he turns away from the wall and sud stops short. Across the room, under a sign that reads, "USED, SLASHED PRICES, AS IS" is a beat up old Fender Stratocaster with chunk missing out of the top of the body. Harold smiles.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And then Harold saw it: a damaged and terribly mistreated Fender staring back at him. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Despite its obvious maladies, the guitar spoke with conviction and swagger. In fact, it looked Harold directly in the eye, and very plainly stated, "I rock.” cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold approaches a young, pimply faced SALES REPRESENTAT in a large room with various books of sheet music filed i bins. He carries his briefcase in one hand and his Fender in the other.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Uh... excuse me...

dialogues.speaker: SALES REPRESENTATIVE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Well... I want to learn the guitar. And I... I wanted to know if there was, like, a book or a pamphlet or something.

dialogues.speaker: SALES REPRESENTATIVE
dialogues.text: Sure. Sure. What is it you want to play?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (pause) Guitar.

dialogues.speaker: SALES REPRESENTATIVE
dialogues.text: Right. What kind of guitar?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (pause. holding up the Fender) This guitar.

dialogues.speaker: SALES REPRESENTATIVE
dialogues.text: No. Like... Okay. Okay. What kind of music do you listen to?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I don't really listen to music.

dialogues.speaker: SALES REPRESENTATIVE
dialogues.text: Oh dude... alright. What kind of music does the person who will be listening to you play the guitar listen to? Harold looks at him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: And for the first time in his life, Harold Crick honestly wondered what anarchist bakers listen to. Blackout. The following appears on screen: “Celebrate this chance to be alive and breathing." --Tool

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay and Penny sit against the wall of an emergency room. Kay fiddles compulsively with a wadded tissue and Penny t notes as they watch PATIENTS wait to be called by an old, dry-looking NURSE. Penny points to an OLD MAN WITH A BROKEN LEG across the r
