dialogues.text: What about him?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Probably fell in the shower. Not dead.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Okay. The woman in the blue. Kay looks. A WOMAN holds a severe head wound.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Hit with a skillet by an angry neighbor. Interesting, but after some stitches, she'll live. A gurney is rushed by with a YOUNG MAN writhing and screa from a gunshot wound. He's immediately rushed through the doors.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: There you go.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: No. Shot in a gang fight. (pause) Harold's not in a gang.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Man in tweed. A little man hunched over nervously in the corner, wearin tweed jacket.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: There's nothing wrong with him. He just likes looking at sick people.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Oddly spoken with disdain.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: This isn't working. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: You haven't even--

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I toid you this wasn't going to--

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: dust try it and see what--

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Penny. These people aren't dead... they're just maimed.

dialogues.speaker: . PENNY
dialogues.text: Listen, it's better than-- Kay gets up and walks across the room, past sick and suff patients, beginning to tear little shreds from the tissue She approaches the check-in booth.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Excuse me-- where are the dying people? The CHECK-IN NURSE just stares at her blankly. Penny puts her head in her hands.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Most of these people are sick or injured... which is great, don't get me wrong-- But they're gonna get better, which really doesn't help. Is there-- Is there any way to see the people who aren't going to get better?

dialogues.speaker: CHECK-IN NURSE
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I'd like to see~- if at all possible-- the one's who aren't gonna make it. The dead for sure ones.

dialogues.speaker: CHECK-IN NURSE
dialogues.text: I... Are you...? You can't~- Are you... I'm sorry. Are you suffering from anything?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Just writer's block.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold sits on Dave's couch, practicing the guitar, referencing an open tablature book that rests in front of him. He tries as best he can to hum along to his relative simple guitar playing. Harold's watch looks on (peacefully). (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: With every awkward strum, despite his approaching demise, Harold felt a little more at peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold and Dave sit across from one another at the dining room table, eating their sandwiches and laughing.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -Harold no longer ate alone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAROLD brushes his teeth in Dave's bathroom without rhyme reason, yet bobs his head along with an imaginary beat.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: He no longer counted brush strokes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold sits out on Dave's fire escape eating cereal and looking out at the city as Dave hurriedly gets dressed fo work.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He no longer worried about the time it took to put on his tie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold strolls past the bus stop and towards a park, look at the stiff commuters with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He no longer counted his steps to the bus stop...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold sits in a matinee of Manhattan, eating popcorn and laughing by himself.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Instead, Harold did that which had terrified him before. That which had eluded him Monday thru Friday for so Many years... Harold lets out a hearty laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold walks past the bus stop again and watches the same commuters from that morning, now exhausted, flustered and frustrated, exiting the bus. He tries to hide his glee. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: That which the unrelenting lyrics of those numerous punk rock songs told him to do. (pause) Harold Crick lived his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold once again sits on the couch, strumming the guitar with more confidence. He sings with vigor, his hand pound on the strings, his head rocking.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And with every strum, he became stronger in who he was, what he wanted, and why he was alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold crawls into bed, still bobbing. He moves his lapto case off the bed, gently removes his wristwatch and place it on the nightstand next to him. He turns the light off and crawls into bed.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: But despite resuscitating his life, reviving his hope and developing a few wicked calluses, Harold's journey was still incomplete. (pause) And Harold's wristwatch wasn't about to let him miss another opportunity. Suddenly Harold's wristwatch begins to glow. Harold at fi looks at the watch, but then notices what his watch is ca light upon: A file, peeking out of Harold's laptop case, and on its t a name: Ana Pascal. Harold looks at his watch, then takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold approaches the bakery, carrying a large carton. He fortunately arrives just as Ana is locking the bakery up the night. She turns and sees him approach.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Mx. Crick.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (pause) Hi.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: (pause) Hi.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Iouh... I'm glad I caught you.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Oh.’ Why?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Well..: (pause) ,I wanted to bring you these. He holds out the carton, filled with several squat little bags filled with various types of powder. She looks, puzz

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: {not impressed) Really?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Yeah,..

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: So, you're not allowed to accept gifts, but you can give them.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Listen, about the cookies--

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Seems a little inconsistent, doesn’t it Mr. Crick?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Listen-~ yes... it seems very inconsistent. But these--

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: You know what... I'll purchase them.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: {embarrased} No. I just... I made a mistake...

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: No. Seriously. I'11 purchase them. What are they? Harold mumbles something.

dialogues.speaker: ANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (sighs) I brought you flours. Her attitude suddenly drops. She just looks at him. Slowl she smiles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: That's... uh... that's surprisingly funny. She begins to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: It only took me all day to come up with.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: You uh... you carried these all the way here?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I would have carried them anywhere. Suddenly she stops and looks at him. They stare at each other for a moment. Her lips part. His fingers twitch. Harold's watch looks on (anxiously). Harold's watch waits. Then...

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ms. Pascal... I-.. (pause) I've been odd, and I know I've been odd and... (pause) I want you.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BAROLD
dialogues.text: There are so many reasons; so many influences in my... uh, in my life, that are telling me, at times quite literally, that I should ignore the common wisdom and come here and bring you these. (pause) But I'm doing it because I want you.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: (pause) You... “want™ me?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: In no uncertain terms.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: I... uh... um... (pause) Wow. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pause) I... isn’t there some... some very _ clear, established... rule about fraternization, or a particular... uh...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buditor/Auditee protocol.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Protocol. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Yes. ‘But I don’t care.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Because I want you. She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Do you mind carrying those a little farther? :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bus stops and the two get out and begin to walk down th street, Harold carrying the flour and Ana carrying a take out bag. She is laughing at something he's just said. Suddenly Ana stops.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Would you like to come up?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Um... to your place?

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Uh... well...

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Come up.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I guess... I guess I could.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Have dinner with me.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Uh... I'm... uh... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Wasn't that the idea with the flours and everything?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Honestly... I only figured it out up to "I want you."

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Listen: I think I like you, Mr. Crick. And before I do anything rash, I'd like to make sure.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Really? I was pretty sure you hated me?

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: No. I... I think I like you. You definitely have a certain quality that makes me want to eat near you. So I want you to come up. Harold's watch looks on (longingly).

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (pause) I'd be honored. She leads him up quickly up the stoop of a Brownstone apartment.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: I've never had anyone, ever, in my whole life [tell me they want me]-- (pause) Okay. I uh... I think I got a little too excited. I don't live here. He can't help but laugh.

dialogues.speaker: ANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Iouh... I'm... that way a few doors. INT. ANA’S APARTMENT ~- CONTINUOUS Harold and Ana finish their sushi at Ana's quaint dining room table. Her apartment is small, but very cute and uniquely homey, with the occasional “U.S. Out of My Uteru poster for good measure.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: (continuing) Is it really that bad?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Oh yeah... once this demented Portuguese guy got so upset about the audit he tried to take a contract out on my life. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: What? HAROLD. ‘ Yeah... he was nuts though. He got caught when he went to have the contract notarized. She laughs again. She points to his plate. Ana takes

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Good?

dialogues.speaker: . HAROLD
dialogues.text: Very.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Good. Let me... Let me just clean up. If you want... you can relax on the couch. oo the plates into the kitchen. Harold meanders over to the couch which is a total mess. He moves some laundry aside, revealing an acoustic guitar. He looks up. He look back at the guitar.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Bo you play the guitar?

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: No. Someone traded it to me for a wedding cake. Wait... does that mean I have to claim it on my taxes now?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I'll leave it out of my final report.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Do you play?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Not really. I only know one song. She returns from the kitchen. He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Play it.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No. I don't even know it that well.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: It's the best way to seduce a woman, you know... provided you don’t play, "Yes, We Have No Bananas."

dialogues.speaker: ANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Okay... Harold goes and picks up the guitar and has a seat on the couch. He picks at the strings a little.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Um... okay. Keep in mind I just learned.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Okay. He begins to strum the opening chords to "Punk Rock Girl" the Dead Milkmen (track 6 on your cd). He hits the main riff and begins to sing:

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One Saturday I took a walk to Zipperhead/ I met a girl there and she almost knocked me dead/ Punk Rock Girl/ Please look at me/ What do you see/ Let's travel ‘round the world/ Just you and me punk rock girl... Harold continues to strum and smiles shyly.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I tapped her on the shoulder and said do you have a beau/ She looked at me and smiled and said she did not know/ Punk Rock Girl/ Give me a chance/ Let's go slam dance/ We'll dress like Minnie Pearl/ Just you and me punk rock girl... We went to the Philly Pizza Company/ And ordered some hot tea/ The waitress said “Well, no... we only have it iced."/ So we jumped up on the table/ And shouted “Anarchy!"/ And someone played a Beach Boys song/ On the juke box/ It was California Dreamin'/ And so we started screamin' on such a winter's day... Ana purses her lips and taps her feet.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She took me to her parents for a Sunday meal/ Her father took one look at me and he began to squeal/ Punk Rock Girl/ It makes no sense/ Your dad is the Vice President/ Just ask the Duke of Earl/ Yeah, you're for me punk rock girl... Harold stops. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAROLD (CONT’D} Okay. Now there's a solo part that I can’t do.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Skip it. Harold shrugs and resumes playing. Ana just stares at him her eyes alight.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: We went to a shopping mall/ And laughed at all the shoppers/ And .security guards trailed us/ To a record shop/ We asked for Mojo Nixon/ They said, "He don't work here."/ We said, "If you don't got Mojo Nixon/ Then your store could use some fixin'... We got into her car, away we started rollin'/. I said how much you pay for this, she said--~ Suddenly Ana grabs the guitar by the neck, abruptly endin the song.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Nothin' man... it's stolen... They stare at each other for a moment, their lips quiveri ghey suddenly kiss and the actual song kicks in, in full orce: DEAD’ MILKMEN Punk Rock Girl/ You look so wild/ Let's have a child/ We'll name her Minnie Pearl/ Just you and me/ Eat fudge banana swirl/ Just you and me/ We'll travel ‘round the world/ Just you and me... PUNK ROCK GIRL!!! The song ends. But, Harold and Ana continue to kiss, deep and fully, unaware of anything else. We wait for them to stop, which they don't. The song retu

dialogues.speaker: DEAD MILKMEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Punk Rock Girl/ You look so wild/ Let's have a child/ We'll name her Minnie Pearl/ Just you and me/ Eat fudge banana swirl/ Just you and me/ We'll travel ‘round the world/ Just you and me... PUNK ROCK GIRL!!! Ana takes her shirt off, but they don’t stop kissing. She begins to take his shirt off. The song just returns.

dialogues.speaker: DEAD MILKMEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Punk Rock Girl/ You look so wild/ Let's have a child/ We'll name her Minnie Pearl/ Just you and me/ Eat fudge banana swirl/ Just you and me/

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DEAD MILKMEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll travel ‘round the world/ Just you and me... PUNK ROCK GIRL!!! Harold parts his lips just enough to speak.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Ms. Pascal, I...

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: I know... I want you too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is dark and all we can see are shadows and silhouettes but the sounds are decidedly sexual. They suddenly take a moment...

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I'm not counting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera hangs above Harold as he lies in bed next to A Both are asleep, Ana tucked in Harold's clavicle, Harold flat on his back. The camera slowly descends, drawing clo to his face. It swings to reveal the room: the socialist propaganda, the red star flag, the sleek furniture... and back to Harold, who rests peacefully... tranquil, still.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Harold's life, like the life of every human being, was filled with moments both significant and mundane. He opens his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But to Harold, those moments remained entirely indistinguishable... except for this. Ana sighs and nuzzles his chest.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As Ana let out a soft sigh and repositioned herself against him, Harold knew, somewhere, this was one of the significant moments. He knew she had fallen in love with him. Harold smiles and simply closes his eyes.  80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ana wakes up to find Harold excitedly putting his clothes on. .

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Harold? He looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Good morning! He grabs her and gives her a huge kiss.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: What... What are you...?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I have to go... I'm sorry. I really... (pause) You're awesome.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: I am?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Entirely. I uh... I just... I'm sorry I have to rush.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: It's... is something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No. Everything's great. Everything's perfect. I'll... Ana. I'11 explain it all later. But I have to go... (pause. looks at his watch) I heard something. Something very important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay exits a small, poorly maintained market carrying thre packs of cigarettes and a package of travel tissues. She ceremoniously packs each cigarette pack and puts each in separate pocket. She then opens up the tissues and remove one then puts the tissues away. She takes out a pack of cigarettes, opens it, removes a cigarette, puts in her mo and is about to light it when a YOUNG WORKER spills a box fresh Granny Smith apples. The apples topple and roll around the sidewalk, one in particular quickly rolling into the street. Kay stops. She doesn't light the cigarette. For a moment she just stares at the apple which comes to rest on its s in the road. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: My God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold comes into Professor Hilbert's office without knoc interrupting Hilbert in the middle of standing and readin

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Harold?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Professor Hilbert-- Hilbert mutes the television which Harold notices is play an interview between two dour looking women on some book channel.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Professor Hilbert... It's a comedy.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: A comedy. I... this woman... she... last night... (pause) She's fallen in love with me.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: She has?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: The voice confirmed it in the middle of the night.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: That's... Harold that's wonderful. It completely nullifies my list but... Harold, that's fantastic.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What list?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Oh. He hands Harold the list.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These are the seven living authors whose prior work would seem to make them likely candidates to write your story, based on the criteria you and I have already determined. If your narrator is alive... she's on this list.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Wow. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: But it appears the list is of little use to you now. HAROLD. I suppose. Although I can hang on to it--

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Hold on a minute... Hilbert turns up the volume on the television. Perhaps to our surprise, one of the dour women is in fact Kay, who s in a black: Donna Karan suit across from a very smarmy-lo ANCHORWOMAN with short, sensible hair. The interview is obviously years old and Kay is much healthier.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh. Just a rerun. This woman: Karen Eiffel... one of my favorite authors... beautiful tragedies... just beautiful. Watch.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHORWOMAN
dialogues.text: {overly dry) -~and we, of course, anticipate the next book.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Oh. Thanks. I. just started.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHORWOMAN
dialogues.text: And may I ask what this book will be about?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Well... It’s about inter~ connectivity... and the looming certainty of death... men's fashion accessories.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I think... I think I might go... Harold folds the list to take with him.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHORWOMAN
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. (deadpan) Sounds great... may I ask what it's called?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: “Death and Taxes." Harold stops and quickly looks at the television.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHORWOMAN
dialogues.text: {without feeling) Wow. You know, I'm from Texas. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ANCHORWOMAN
dialogues.text: Born and raised in San Antonio. In fact, that's where they have Space Camp.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: No. Not. No. Not Texas. Taxes. "Death and Taxes." Death and Taxes. Death and Taxes. Death and Taxes. The words repeat themselves as we cut between the television and Harold, w eyes widen as he hears those words repeatedly in his head He suddenly breaks out of his daze.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (abruptly) Oh my God. That's her. (pause) That's her.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: That's her. That's the voice. That's... She's the narrator. (pause) That's her.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Harold. Harold. Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I'm positive.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: (pause) Oh no...

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Why? What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: First of all, she wasn't on my list.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Oh. Well...

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: And she... She doesn't... (pause) Harold. She kills people. Harold just looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: In every book. She... The books are all about... They die. She kilis them. .

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: The heroes. Harold quickly looks...

dialogues.speaker: . HAROLD
dialogues.text: Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Harold. I... she's untraceable. I've... believe me. I used to teach a class on her work. .I've written her letters. She's a hermit. A recluse. I mean... she hasn't published anything in ten years. Harold goes to Hilbert's stacks and finds one of the many copies of Kay's books and opens it up to the copyright pa He grabs a pencil and a document from Hilbert's desk.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Can I write on this?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: No. Harold you-- Harold ignores him and begins to write anyway, mumbling t himself.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: ..-Edison Press... 2267 Wallace...

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Harold, even if you find--

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Okay. I'm gonna find her--

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Harold, listen, she only--

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I'm gonna-- It‘s. I'm gonna find her.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Harold--

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I have to do something. I'll find her. Harold bolts. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: (Harold can't hear...) Harold. She only writes tragedies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay enters the loft (carrying yellow sheets of paper) to find Penny already at work. Kay seems oddly not depressed

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I figured out how to kill Harold this morning.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Excellent. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: It's perfect. I can't believe I didn't think of it earlier. It's... it's simple, ironic, possibly heartbreaking.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: That's very good to hear. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold bounds into the loft-like, upscale offices of Edis Press: exposed brick walls, old printing presses, elevate offices, etc. A YOUNG RECEPTIONIST reads a magazine behind her desk.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Hi. Hello. Hi.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: May I help you?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I need to speak with Karen Eiffel.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Karen Eiffel. One of your authors. I need to speak with her. It's urgent.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Well... sir, she's not here.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I know. I just... I need to find her. I need to know where she is.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: We're just the publishers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Right. Of course. But you have to have a way I can contact her.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: We have the address where her fan Mail is sent.

dialogues.speaker: , HAROLD
dialogues.text: I can't send mail. This is urgent.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Is it a family emergency?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No. Not really.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Then how do you know her? Harold takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD

I figured... it was easy... and I was counting everything anyway. And, I had this unwavering belief in a world of absolutes. And I thought somehow I could prove it. But I couldn't. dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No.. I read it. And I loved it. And there's only one way it can end. It ends with me dying. I mean, I don't have much background in literary... anything, but this seems simple enough... (pause) : It's my fate. I can't escape it. You can't escape it either. As much as I want to believe that you or I or Professor Hilbert can control when and where I die, or when and where I fall in love, or even when and where my watch goes on the fritz... it's just not the truth. All I know is that a series of events has been set into motion... that none of us are able to do anything about. And so we all have to learn to accept it. And move on with our lives. For however long they last. He hands her the manuscript.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I love your book. And I think you should finish it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold enters his apartment. He looks briefly at the plas that now constitutes his front wall. He chuckles and continues towards the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The night before his death, Harold unceremoniously went about some necessary business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold goes to his closet and pulls out his nicest suit a his orange tie.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He chose a suit to wear the next day... He picked up a few odds and ends...  105.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He made few phone calls he had heen putting off.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Hi. Hi. Yes. Hi. Yes. Listen... does your program have an age limit? (pause. smiles) Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold stands, waiting for the bus, holding his suit and overnight bag.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And he traveled to Ms. Pascal's where she made him dinner and the two watched old movies. INT. ANA‘S APARTMENT -- CONTINUOUS Harold holds Ana in his arms as the glow of the televisio washes over them. Ana laughs at something she sees, Harol chuckles, understandably distant.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It was a nice enough evening and in any other circumstance would seem commonplace. In fact, the only thing that made this night significant was the morning it preceded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ana and Harold look at each other, their heads on their respective pillows. Ana traces her fingertips across Haro shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (softly) I have to tell you something.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: (teasing) Is it a secret?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Sort of. (long pause) I adore you.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: (touched) I adore you. Harold’s watch looks on (despondently) . (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Was that it?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: ‘No... I have to tell you this... and I want you to just listen carefully: Harold takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pause. sincerely) You can subtract the value of the food you give away every night to the shelter as a charitable contribution. It, in fact, amounts to more than what you're currently withholding and doesn't break any tax laws. She looks at him, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Harold. The whole idea is to break the tax laws.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Well... this way you' re not paying for defense or going to jail, and you can still write whatever nasty letters you want.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: You're very strange, Harold Crick. But I like you anyway. She gives him another kiss.

dialogues.speaker: ANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Goodnight . She puts her head back on her pillow and closes her eyes. Harold looks at her for a moment. Then he turns over, pic up his watch, and sets its alarm. Blackout. The following appears on screen: "I can't wait to die. I can find this song. It's where I'll find my life when I'm through with my present one." Shellac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun lifts above the city's skyline, splitting through the buildings and reflecting off the steel and glass... Traffic moves down the interstate... Street cleaners motor through the streets... JOGGERS pass each other on the sidewalks... Buses leave their terminals...  107.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Harold sits at the edge of the bed, staring out the w at the city. His wrist watch changes to 7:15. It begins to beep. Harold quickly turns it off. Ana rustles. Harold takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold brushes his teeth, not paying attention to how he does it.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That particular Thursday morning was brisk and unsuspecting, as was Harold... Harold locks up, coyly smiling.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He brushed his teeth, albeit in vain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ana still sleeps, Harold flips his tie over itself.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: He prepared for work, in vain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold eats some cereal while looking through a morning p

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And he ate a sensible breakfast, also in vain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold goes to the nightstand, retrieves his watch, and p it on. He gives Ana a tender kiss on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (softly) Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold calmly walks down the sidewalk, taking in the city air as much as he can.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Much had changed for Harold over the past few weeks: his attitude towards (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: work, his eating habits, his habitual counting, his love life, his ability to rock... but of all the ‘transmutations Harold Crick had undergone, perhaps the most significant was that he was no longer late for the 8:17 Faraday Bus... Harold continues to walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold stands at the bus stop, a few other commuters arou him including the, Polish woman from before.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What Harold had never understood about that Wednesday two weeks prior, was that the time he received from his fellow commuter was, in fact, three full minutes later than the actual time, and therefore three full minutes later than the time to which his watch had been previously set. Not the worst of oversights, one might assume... but it meant that Harold had been living his life three minutes ahead of schedule. And if Harold had not set his watch to the incorrect time, Harold would have continued to barely catch the 8:17 Faraday bus,’ and he would not be at the bus stop precisely at 8:16 this particular Thursday. An otherwise ignorable fact, until the unthinkable occurred... Suddenly And You Will Know Us By The Trail of Dead's "How Near, How Far" (track 8 on your cd) begins to play. :01 The blonde boy, heimet on, comes unsuspectingly speed down the sidewalk on his bicycle. :05 Harold smiles at the Polish Woman. :07 The bus comes rounding the corner and towards the bus stop. :10 All the other commuters step forward towards the bus. Harold remains staring at the sky. 113 The boy approaches the crowd of commuters quickly... :16 As does the bus. :20 Harold continues to stare at the sky. 723 The boy swerves to miss the commuters, spilling his bicycle off the curb where it topples, sending him into t street. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: :28 The boy tries to get up but his loose helmet has swun around to cover his face. 233 Harold calmly steps out into the street. :38 The bus begins to screech as it tries to brake. :40 Harold pushes the boy out of the way, but finds himse in the path of the bus. Harold has just enough time to tu his hand flying up to cover his head before... SCREECH.... The bus SMACKS into Harold. Harold's watch shatters as the bus hits it. Glass and sma bits of metal fly everywhere. Harold's body distorts as i is pounded by the front of the bus. Harold is sent flying. He hits the ground with a decided THUD. His body lies lifeless on the asphalt. As the crowd begin to gather around him, blood can be seen pouring from his head. Despite the chaos that surrounds him, his body rest in perfect stillness. Harold's body rests, lifeless, in the middle of the stree From above, we see his legs are buckled underneath him an blood has formed a halo around his head, his arm snapped like a twig. But his face is peaceful. Harold Crick lies dead in the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay sits at her desk, typing. She's obviously crying, her hands trembling. She reaches in her pocket and pulls out a wadded tissue p which she unravels, revealing a cigarette butt. She is Shaking so much she can barely coax the cigarette between her lips. She reaches across the desk for a lighter. Her fingers are no longer functional as she tries in vain get it to light. But she can't. And then she stops. She stares at the cigarette. She swallows her tears and crumples the cigarette in her hand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And You Will Know Us By The Trail of Dead begins once aga {track 8 cont'd). The bus door opens and the middle-aged black women, incre upset, steps off the bus. She wears a driver's blue unifo her name patch reading, Carla. She is immediately comfort as someone quickly says, "It's not your fault..." The blonde boy gets up. Other than a scraped elbow, he's perfectly fine. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is attended’ to by a CONCERNED WOMAN who leads him to curb. But most of the activity surrounds Harold, who has not mo People hold ONLOOKERS back, a' few people sob in despair. Most just stare in horror. And then suddenly, with the single violin note, Harold's eyes open. . With a rush of sound, a cacophony of people can be heard, saying "You're gonna be okay!" "Call an ambulance!" "Don' move him!" Harold looks at all the peering faces including the sweet looking Polish woman.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Am I... (pause) Am I dead?

dialogues.speaker: POLISH WOMAN
dialogues.text: (kindly) No. ‘You are alive.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (pause) Why? The Polish woman shrugs reassuringly.

dialogues.speaker: POLISH WOMAN
dialogues.text: (pause) If it is any consolation, you are hurt very very badly. Harold smiles at her, Blackout. The following appears on screen: "Of all the minutes that were taken away... will your wat be waiting?" ~- At The Drive-In

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professor Hilbert stares out his window, looking at the activity of the college forlorn. He sips some juice. There is a knock at his door.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Come in. He doesn't pull away from the window as we can hear the s of the DOOR OPENING and CLOSING behind him.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Excuse me... Are you Professor Hilbert? Professor Hilbert turns. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There stands Karen Eiffel. In his office. Holding the manuscript.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: I... uh... uh... yes...

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Hi. I'm Karen Eiffel. Professor Hilbert looks at her, amazed.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I believe we have a mutual acquaintance.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Please... please... sit down.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I just came by... to... uh... (pause) Here.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Is this...?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Oh... So... you finished it? Typed it and everything?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: This morning.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: I see. Professor Hilbert hangs his head with despair.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I think... perhaps... you may be interested in the new ending... Professor Hilbert looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: I'm sorry...?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: The ending. You may want to read it. She offers it to him. He looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold wakes up in a hospital room, sunlight pouring in. His leg is in a cast, his right arm in a sling, his head bandaged and his left wrist is covered in gauze. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A friendly-looking DOCTOR is currently reviewing his file

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Oh... Hi...

dialogues.speaker: . DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Pretty brave thing you did...

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (groggily) What?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Stepping in front of the bus... pretty brave. Kind of stupid. But pretty brave.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Oh. Yeah... (shifting) Ouch. Is uh... Is that boy okay?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Just fine. Scratched up is all.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Good. Am I okay?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Well, you're not dead. On the other hand... (reads, excitedly) Looks like you cracked your head, broke three bones in your leg and foot, suffered four broken ribs, fractured your right arm... and you severed an artery in your left arm which could've been really amazingly a shard of metal watch became lodged in the causing your heart rate to keeping your loss of blood to keep you alive... which cool.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Wow...

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Yeah. bad, but from your artery, slow, down enough is pretty With some physical therapy and a few months of rest you should be fine. Well... sort of. We couldn't remove the shard of watch without risking major muscular damage. It'll be okay, you'll just have a watch piece embedded in your arm for the rest of your life. Harold chuckles and looks at his wrist. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: {pause} You're very lucky to be alive, Mr. Crick.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (pause} Yeah... A NURSE enters.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Dr. Mercator. Mr. Crick has a visitor...

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Sure... The nurse opens the door to the hallway and Ana comes in, carrying a paper plate. She immediately comes to his side

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Harold... She begins to cry.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I'm okay... Harold...

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Hey... I'm alright...

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: I... Harold...

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Ana... I'm okay.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: No you're not. Look at you! You're severely injured. Harold can't help but laugh.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: i'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: I came straight from the bakery... What happened...?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I uh... I stepped in front of a bus.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: {incredulously) Why? .

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I didn't... I wasn't... there was a boy. I pushed him out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I had to keep this boy from being hit.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: You stepped in front of a bus to ,save a little boy...?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I didn't have a choice. (pause) I had to. She kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Harold. If anything had happened to you... it would've broken my rebellious little heart... I... I... {wipes her tears) You don't know how grateful I am you're alive. ‘

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (pause) I’ know... Surprisingly, I am too. Ana takes a breath and calms down a little. She puts the paper plate on the bed next to him.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: Here. I brought you cookies. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professor Hilbert finishes the manuscript. He puts it down on the couch next to him.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: (pause) It's... It's okay. She turns to him. Kay It's not great.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: No. But... it's okay. It's not bad. Not the most amazing piece of American literature in several years but... it's okay.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (pause) You know, I think I'm fine with okay.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: It doesn't make any sense with the rest of the book though.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: No. Not yet. I'll re-write the rest. My assistant said, she said she'd go back to the publisher and request more time. He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Why did you change it?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: (pause) Lots of reasons. But... I realized I couldn't do it.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Because he's real?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: No. Because... (pause) It's a book about a man who doesn’t know he's about to die... then dies. But if the man does know he's going to die, and dies anyway... dies willingly, knowing he could stop it... you tell me... (pause) Isn't that the type of man you want to keep alive? He stares at her. Suddenly she stops and looks at him. They stare at each other for a moment. Her lips part. His The The Then... fingers twitch. skull on Hilbert's carpets looks on (anxiously). manuscript reveals their lopsided fate. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: {pause) Thank you for your letters. I'm sorry I never wrote back.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: It's okay. Thank you for your novels. The two just look at each other awkwardly for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Is there... uh... is there any chance you'd like to get a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Yes. Wo. I mean... I can't. TI quit.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Coffee?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Yes. Why? Do I seem sluggish?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: No. No. Actually, I just quit myself. I mean, smoking.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: When did you quit?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Page 311.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Ah... They smile at each other.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How about something else...?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Okay. What do you feel like...?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: I don't know. Seems like a good opportunity to start a new routine.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Tea...?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: Tea and scones...?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: That... that sounds... yes. (pause) You know, I've heard of an excellent bakery. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR HILBERT
dialogues.text: (nods) Sounds good. Maybe we can visit Harold. See how he's doing.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: You just read how he's doing. He's doing fine. Professor Hilbert stands and takes her hand. They go to t door and out into the hallway. We hear him walk away and the office door close as we zoo in on the last paragraph, which begins with the words, "A Harold took a bite of Bavarian Sugar Cookie..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold takes a bite of Bavarian Sugar Cookie...

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: As Harold took a bite of Bavarian Sugar Cookie, he finally felt as if everything was going to be okay. (pause) Sometimes, when we lose ourselves in fear and despair, in routine and constancy, in hopelessness and tragedy... there are Bavarian Sugar cookies. Ana strokes his face... his shoulders...

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And, fortunately, when there aren't any cookies we can still find reassurance in a familiar hand on our skin... cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Or a kind and loving gesture... Penny takes a pack of nicotine patches and places them squarely on Kay's laptop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave opens up a manila envelope and pulls out the content

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Or a subtle encouragement... It's an application for Space Camp-

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Or a loving embrace...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy's father hugs him tightly.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Or an offer of comfort. Carla is surrounded by co-workers who console her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We flash back to the scene with Kay in the emergency room the young gunshot victim being carried in... a NARRATOR Not to mention hospital gurneys...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We flash back to the scene with Hilbert at the swimming p putting his nose plugs in...

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: And nose plugs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We flash back to the first scene in the bakery, the homel man eating his Danish.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: And uneaten Danish... INT. ANA'’S BEDROOM -- FLASHBACK We flash back to the scene with Harold and Ana looking at each other, their heads on their pillows.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: And soft-spoken secrets...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We flash back to the scene with Harold in the music store

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: And Fender Stratocasters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We flash back to the scene with Harold reading the manusc on the bus.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: And maybe, the occasional piece of fiction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Flaming Lips' "Do You Realize?" (track 9 on your cd) begins to play. Ana has a pen and is drawing anarchist symbols and propaganda on Harold's cast. He chuckles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: And we must remember that all these things, the nuances, the anomalies, the subtleties which we assume only accessorize our days, are in fact here for a much larger and nobler cause. {pause} They are here to save our lives. Finished drawing, Ana affectionately touches the gauze on Harold's wrist.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I know the idea seems strange. But I also know that it just so happens to be true. (pause) And so it was... a wristwatch saved Harold Crick. He looks at her and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pan down the final page of. the manuscript, through wh until we reach these words: The End.
